discussion.content:
Neighbor Discovery Protocol is an umbrella that defines these mechanisms:
Subsitute of ARP – Since ARP has been removed in IPv6, IPv6 follows a newer way to find the link-layer addresses of nodes on the local link. This new mechanism uses a mix of ICMPv6 messages and multicast addresses.
Stateless Auto-Configuration – This mechanism allows nodes on the local link to configure their IPv6 addresses by themselves by using a mix of ICMPv6 messages and multicast addresses.
Router Redirection – The router sends ICMPv6 messages to an IPv6 node to inform it of the presence of a better router address on the same local link to reach a destination network.

questions.question_text: Which protocol does ipv6 use to discover other ipv6 nodes on the same segment?
Which command can you enter to verify that a 128-bit address is live and responding?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Ping" is the correct Answer. There is no command like "ping ipv6" the command is "ping

certainly ping ipv6
D is the correct answer

"To diagnose basic network connectivity when using IPv6, use the ping IPv6 command in user EXEC or privileged EXEC mode."

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/ipv6/command/reference/ipv6_book/ipv6_10.html
"Ping" is the correct Answer. There is no command like "ping ipv6" the command is "ping"
You don't need another command to ping an ipv6 address, the command remains "ping" and you just specify an ipv6 address instead of an ipv4 address.

questions.question_text: Which option is the industry-standard protocol for EtherChannel?

discussion.content:
There are two protocols used for negotiating EtherChannel and Link Aggregation. We can configure Etherchannel in three ways in Cisco Switches.
Port Aggregation Protocol (PAgP) - Cisco Proprietary protocol
IEEE Link Aggregation Protocol (LACP) - Industry Standard
Manual Etherchannel Configuration - Without using any negotiation protocol listed above
Should be AE, it doesn't prevent overlapping

questions.question_text: For which two reasons was RFC 1918 address space defining (Choose two.)

choices.A: to preserve public IPv4 address space
choices.B: to reduce the occurrence of overlapping IP addresses
choices.D: reduce the size of ISP routing tables
choices.C: to preserve public IPv6 address space

questions.question_text: What will happen if a private IP address is assigned to a public interface connected to an ISP?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Addresses in a private range will not be routed on the Internet backbone

choices.A: A conflict of IP addresses happens, because other public routers can use the same range.
choices.D: The NAT process will be used to translate this address to a valid IP address.
choices.B: Addresses in a private range will not be routed on the Internet backbone.
choices.C: Only the ISP router will have the capability to access the public network.
